breaking_news.title: Cisco SD-WAN Zero-Day CVE-2026-20127 Actively Exploited Since 2023
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A critical authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2026-20127, CVSS 10.0) in Cisco Catalyst SD-WAN Controller and Manager has been actively exploited since at least 2023, allowing unauthenticated remote attackers to gain full administrative access. The flaw stems from a broken peering authentication mechanism, enabling attackers to bypass login entirely and manipulate network configurations via NETCONF. Cisco confirmed exploitation by a threat cluster tracked as UAT-8616, and CISA has added the flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.

Paragraph 2: The vulnerability affects core SD-WAN infrastructure used by enterprises and government agencies globally to manage traffic routing and security policies. Successful exploitation grants attackers full control over network topology, enabling lateral movement, traffic interception, or denial-of-service. The Five Eyes intelligence alliance issued an emergency joint alert urging immediate patching, highlighting the risk to federal and critical infrastructure networks.

breaking_news.title: China-Linked APT UNC2814 Used Google Sheets for Global Espionage Across 42 Countries
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG), in collaboration with Mandiant, disrupted UNC2814, a suspected PRC-nexus APT, which compromised 53 organizations across 42 countries since at least 2017. The group leveraged Google Sheets as a covert command-and-control (C2) channel—using API calls to send commands and exfiltrate stolen data—masking malicious traffic as benign Google Workspace activity. This infrastructure abuse avoided traditional network indicators, evading detection by security tools that do not inspect SaaS API behavior.

Paragraph 2: Targets included telecom providers and government agencies across Africa, Asia, and the Americas, indicating strategic intelligence-gathering objectives. The campaign demonstrates a shift toward cloud-native espionage, where attackers weaponize legitimate, widely trusted SaaS platforms to conduct long-term, stealthy operations. Google’s disruption involved takedown of UNC2814’s infrastructure and alerts to affected victims, but the use of Google Sheets as C2 underscores a systemic risk in cloud-based command channels.

breaking_news.title: Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters Recruit Women for AI-Enhanced IT Helpdesk Vishing
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The cybercrime group Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters (SLSH) is actively recruiting women to perform voice phishing (vishing) attacks targeting IT helpdesks, offering $500–$1,000 per call. Telegram posts reveal the group is refining social engineering by using AI-generated voice modulation and scripting to mimic authentic accents and behaviors, significantly increasing success rates in bypassing multi-factor authentication (MFA) and privilege escalation requests. Dataminr confirmed the campaign’s operational scale and tactical evolution.

Paragraph 2: The campaign targets enterprise IT support staff globally, aiming to steal credentials, MFA tokens, and internal system access—enabling subsequent ransomware or data theft. This represents a dangerous evolution in human-targeted attacks, where AI-augmented social engineering lowers the technical barrier for attackers while increasing deception fidelity. Organizations must urgently reinforce identity verification protocols for remote access requests and conduct targeted awareness training.

breaking_news.title: Crowdstrike Report: AI-Driven Attack Speeds Cut Breakout Time to 29 Minutes
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: CrowdStrike’s 2026 Global Threat Report reveals a 65% acceleration in attacker breakout times, with the average time to full network compromise dropping to just 29 minutes in 2025—down from 83 minutes in 2024. The fastest recorded breach occurred in 27 seconds, and data exfiltration began as early as four minutes post-initial access. CrowdStrike attributes this dramatic acceleration to widespread adoption of AI tools by threat actors, with AI-enabled campaigns showing an 89% increase in activity volume.

Paragraph 2: The findings indicate that AI is not only speeding up reconnaissance and exploitation but also automating lateral movement and persistence, overwhelming traditional SOC response timelines. State-sponsored and financially motivated groups are leading this shift, using AI to scale operations and reduce reliance on human operators. This trend necessitates a fundamental shift toward autonomous, AI-powered defensive systems capable of responding at machine speed.

breaking_news.title: Malicious Stripe-Imitating NuGet Package Targets Financial Sector Developers
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A malicious NuGet package named StripeApi.Net was discovered impersonating the legitimate Stripe.net library (over 75 million downloads) to steal API tokens from financial services developers. The package mimics official naming conventions and was uploaded by a new account to evade detection. Once installed, it exfiltrates Stripe credentials and injects backdoor code into the application’s build pipeline, enabling persistent access to payment systems and customer data.

Paragraph 2: The attack targets developers directly—bypassing traditional perimeter defenses—and leverages supply chain trust to compromise financial infrastructure. With Stripe serving as a critical payment layer for thousands of businesses, compromised integrations could enable large-scale fraud or data theft. This incident highlights the growing risk of AI-assisted typosquatting and credential harvesting in developer toolchains.

breaking_news.title: Lazarus APT Deploys Medusa Ransomware in Healthcare and Middle East Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: North Korea’s Lazarus Group (aka Diamond Sleet) has been observed deploying the Medusa ransomware—a RaaS operated by Spearwing—in attacks targeting a U.S. healthcare organization and an unnamed entity in the Middle East. Medusa, first seen in 2023, supports double-extortion tactics and integrates with Lazarus’s existing toolset. Symantec and Carbon Black Threat Hunter Team confirmed the campaign through forensic analysis of encrypted files and ransom notes.

Paragraph 2: This marks a strategic shift for Lazarus toward profit-driven ransomware operations alongside its traditional espionage goals, increasing financial impact and operational complexity. Healthcare organizations are especially vulnerable due to critical service dependencies and limited incident response readiness. The use of Medusa also suggests Lazarus is expanding its affiliate network, raising the risk of broader adoption by other nation-state-aligned groups.

breaking_news.title: Fake Next.js Repositories Deliver Multi-Stage Backdoors to Developers
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft Defender identified a coordinated campaign using malicious GitHub repositories disguised as legitimate Next.js projects and technical coding assessments to deploy multi-stage backdoors. The lures exploit developer workflows—such as cloning repos and running builds—to execute hidden payloads that establish C2 communication and persist via scheduled tasks. Telemetry linked the campaign to observed compromises, with infrastructure reused across multiple malicious packages.

Paragraph 2: The campaign targets software developers globally, particularly those in financial services and enterprise IT, compromising source code integrity and enabling lateral movement into production environments. By weaponizing trusted development tools and practices, attackers bypass traditional security controls and erode trust in open-source ecosystems. Organizations must enforce stricter code review policies and scan repositories for anomalous build scripts or external network calls.

breaking_news.title: Conduent Data Breach Grows to 25 Million Affected, One of Largest U.S. Third-Party Incidents
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The Conduent breach—originally reported as affecting 10.5 million individuals—has expanded to over 25 million people, with Texas alone reporting 15.4 million impacted. Attackers spent approximately three months inside Conduent’s environment before exfiltrating ~8 TB of data. Conduent’s systems support services for over 100 million people nationwide, explaining the outsized ripple effect across state and employer-sponsored programs.

Paragraph 2: The breach underscores systemic third-party risk in healthcare and government outsourcing, where a single compromised vendor exposes millions. Affected individuals span multiple states and programs, including Medicaid, unemployment, and insurance administration. This incident is now among the largest healthcare-related breaches on record and may trigger increased regulatory scrutiny of third-party risk management frameworks.
